name: Lazarus Group TTPs: Operation Blacksmith
description: TTPs identified in Lazarus Group's Operation Blacksmith

techniques.comment: Lazarus deployed RATs on the target systems to strategically control them and further its operations.
Lazarus exploited the Log4j vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) to gain initial access to the targets' systems.
Lazarus used the Telegram application protocol as the C2 channel for their RAT.
NineRAT communicates with the C2 server using a DLang-based library implemented to interact with Telegramâ€™s API.
NineRAT communicates with the C2 server via the Telegram app, thus using non-standard ports.
Log4j exploitation leads to Windows Command Shell execution for reconnaissance and initial data collection.
Lazarus used the Windows service command to set up persistence for the NineRAT malware; a BAT script was used to do this.
In Operation Blacksmith, Lazarus exploited the Log4j vulnerability on publicly facing VMWare Horizon servers for initial access.
Threat actors created a user account on the system and granted it administrative privileges.
NineRAT executed commands to fingerprint the infected systems.
Through commands like 'ipconfig', 'ver', 'wmic os get osarchitecture', 'net user', and 'wmic/netstat-nap tcp', Lazarus was able to discover valuable system information.
After creating their own user account, attackers dumped credentials using tools like ProcDump and MimiKatz to gain broader access.
Lazarus used the WMIC command to discover the antivirus product running on the system. This could help in creating evasion strategies.
Lazarus used the command 'tasklist' to discover processes running on the system.
Lazarus incorporated a PowerShell command to download the next stage payload from a hardcoded remote URL.
Lazarus created a local account which matches the account documented by Microsoft.
NineRAT communicates with the Telegram channel to facilitate data exfiltration.
Lazarus used the 'net localgroup administrators' command to discover users on the system.
NineRAT, deployed by Lazarus, accepted preliminary commands from the Telegram-based C2 channel.

Lazarus used PowerShell to perform the initial reconnaissance after gaining access, executed commands for credential dumping, used PowerShell commands to download next-stage payloads, and used it for commands to upload files to the C2.
Lazarus used a file hosting site to store exfiltrated data.
Lazarus group used the Windows Startup directory and methods to create persistent mechanisms for their malware.
Lazarus created a .URL file in the Startup directory to run the PowerShell command to download the payload.
DLRAT executed commands to gather preliminary information about the system.
NineRAT performs file and directory discovery functions to provide Lazarus with information about the infected system.
Lazarus modified the registry to dump credentials.
HazyLoad, a reverse proxy tool used by Lazarus, listens on an uncommonly used port.
NineRAT used PowerShell to perform commands to upload files to the C2 and download files from a specified remote location.
